rename.from: PHPUnit 10 Performance issues due to Exporter
rename.to: Values used in assertions are exported for Test\AssertionSucceeded and Test\AssertionFailed events

issue.title: PHPUnit 10.0 significantly slower than PHPUnit 9.6

labels.name: type/performance
labels.description: Issues related to resource consumption (time and memory)

issue.body:
Hi, updating my biggest project from `9.6` to `10.0` shows execution time **doubling** at best.
Here are some numbers:

| PHPUnit | Time | Diff | Memory |
| - | - | - | - |
| `9.6` 1st run | 02:29.786 | Δ | 1.13 GB |
| `9.6` 2nd run | 02:29.785 | Δ | 1.12 GB |
| `9.6` 3rd run | 02:28.535 | Δ | 1.13 GB |
| `10.0` 1st run | 06:09.392 | +148% | 1.18 GB |
| `10.0` 2nd run | 06:19.358 | +154% | 1.17 GB |
| `10.0` 3rd run | 06:10.374 | +148% | 1.17 GB |

Some context:

* No code change was needed, only `composer.json` has been edited
* No Listener/Extension used
* `--no-coverage` flag in place
* `--no-logging` flag in place
* `--do-not-cache-result` flag in place

I'd like to help you idenfity the issue, but I need some clue: how could I effectively compare PHPUnit's internals from `9.6` to `10.0`?

body: I can confirm this can have a huge impact: on my biggest project exporting `$value` makes the test suite run 3x times slower than stripping away that single line of code from PHPUnit.
I have to say that I am surprised that this has such a huge impact, simply because I have never used assertions on object graphs so large that exporting them became noticably expensive.

The most recurring use case for me is where you have a variable that might be an `object` or `null`, so the first assertion on the variable is `assertNotNull`:

```php
$myBigObject = getMyBigObjectOrNull();
self::assertNotNull($myBigObject);
self::assertTrue($myBigObject->active()); // And so on
```

I have a hundred of snippets like this in my test folder.

rename.from: Values used in assertions are exported for Test\AssertionSucceeded and Test\AssertionFailed events
rename.to: Values used in assertions are exported for Test\AssertionSucceeded events

body:
Thank you, @muzcb and @Slamdunk for bringing this to my attention!

With the changes in c2fcb8f1bec7773ac1d745078ba9eb4570868e11, we no longer export values used in assertions to emit the `Test\AssertionSucceeded` event. The `Test\AssertionSucceeded::value()` message has been marked as deprecated, it will be removed in PHPUnit 11. Until then, this method will always return `''`.
Thank you very much for your support @sebastianbergmann

After this change PhpUnit 10 is actually faster than 9.5 or 9.6 for us.

Before this change test suite took around  8 minutes with PhpUnit 10, now after this it took only under 2 minutes. 

with 9.6/9.5 it takes about 3 minutes.
@sakarikl That is good to hear, thanks! It is also surprising to hear, as PHPUnit 10 "does more" (event system) than PHPUnit 9, so I have to wonder where this improvement is coming from.
Only change for us was using attributes instead of phpdoc (in covers and dataprovider) and changing data providers to statics.
oh. and paratest was also updated from 6 to 7. Those were all run with WrapperRunner with 4 processes.

issue.title: Tests with DataProvider attribute not represented in ExecutionStarted->testSuite()->tests()

labels.name: feature/events
labels.description: Issues related to PHPUnit's event system

issue.title: Performance issues with PHPUnit 10

repository.name: mockery
repository.description: Mockery is a simple yet flexible PHP mock object framework for use in unit testing with PHPUnit, PHPSpec or any other testing framework. Its core goal is to offer a test double framework with a succinct API capable of clearly defining all possible object operations and interactions using a human readable Domain Specific Language (DSL).

issue.body:
Hi there :wave: 

PHPUnit 10 was recently released and brings a revised event system. Within this event system, among other things, meta information about used objects from expectations are kept, so that the test runner can evaluate them after completion of the tests.
Among other things, Mockery's mock objects are serialized and stored in memory. Due to the fact that a mock object can contain a lot of information, the amount of data grows quite fast, which makes the tests very slow and quickly hits the memory limit.

Trigger can be e.g. an `assertSame`, which uses the `IsIdentical` class in PHPUnit and serializes the data by means of `IsIdentical::toString` from `sebastianbergmann/exporter`. This also serializes the protected properties of the `Mock` class of Mockery, (`$_mockery_expectations`, ...) which could in part contain large structures/object graphs and ultimately lead to said problem.

An example from one of my projects:

PHPUnit 9 + Mockery
```
Time: 00:00.768, Memory: 56.00 MB

OK (440 tests, 1727 assertions)
```

PHPUnit 10 + Mockery
```
Time: 00:02.994, Memory: 183.57 MB

OK (440 tests, 1727 assertions)
```

I created a q+d repo which contains simple testcode, a stacktrace and the event payload within phpunit.
https://github.com/usox/mockery-performance-issue

See also:
- Recent related phpunit issue:  sebastianbergmann/phpunit/issues/5183
- Exporter which causes the serialization https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/exporter/blob/988f65481f95f3080d7b412d4fc863b7d09c36b2/src/Exporter.php#L63

issue.title: Blacklisting of object details for some classes/interfaces

repository.name: exporter
repository.description: Provides the functionality to export PHP variables for visualization

issue.body:
Currently, Prophecy contains a (outdated) copy of the exporter, altered to avoid dumping the internals of Prophecy objects, to make the export much more readable.
It would be great to support such feature in this library directly, allowing Prophecy to use it instead of copying it (making maintenance much easier). See https://github.com/phpspec/prophecy/issues/296#issuecomment-261772701 for the discussion about it.

See https://github.com/phpspec/prophecy/blob/5c324f4951aca87a2de61b7903b75126516b6386/src/Prophecy/Util/ExportUtil.php#L184 for the current implementation.

issue.title: Do not emit `Test\AssertionSucceeded` and `Test\AssertionFailed` events when they do not have subscribers

labels.name: type/enhancement
labels.description: A new idea that should be implemented

labels.name: type/performance
labels.description: Issues related to resource consumption (time and memory)

labels.name: feature/events
labels.description: Issues related to PHPUnit's event system

issue.body:
For instance, in `PHPUnit\Framework\Assert::assertThat()` we have:
```php
Event\Facade::emitter()->testAssertionSucceeded(
    $value,
    $constraint,
    $message,
);
```
The code shown above calls `PHPUnit\Event\DispatchingEmitter::testAssertionSucceeded()` to emit the `PHPUnit\Event\Test\AssertionSucceeded` event.

This is what `PHPUnit\Event\DispatchingEmitter::testAssertionSucceeded()` looked like before c2fcb8f1bec7773ac1d745078ba9eb4570868e11:
```php
public function testAssertionSucceeded(mixed $value, Constraint\Constraint $constraint, string $message): void
{
    $this->dispatcher->dispatch(
        new Test\AssertionSucceeded(
            $this->telemetryInfo(),
            (new Exporter)->export($value),
            $constraint->toString(),
            $constraint->count(),
            $message,
        )
    );
}
```

The `(new Exporter)->export($value)` and `$constraint->toString()` operations are expensive (for (very) complex types, such as large object graphs, for intance). These operations are necessary, though, to ensure that event objects such as `PHPUnit\Event\Test\AssertionSucceeded` are immutable and do not allow subscribers of the respective event to mess with original values.

So far, two performance issues have been reported related to this:

* https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/phpunit/issues/5183
* https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/exporter/issues/18#issuecomment-1446375509

Both of these issues concern the `PHPUnit\Event\Test\AssertionSucceeded` and `PHPUnit\Event\Test\AssertionFailed` events.

Unless `--log-events-text` or `--log-events-verbose-text` is used, PHPUnit itself does not subscribe to either of these two events. They only exist to allow authors of test runner extensions even more insight into how tests are run. This means that by default, the result of the expensive operations mentioned is not used.

PHPUnit's event system only allows subscribers to be registered before the actual tests are run. When we seal the event facade, ie. when we no longer allow subscribers to be registered, we know which events have been subscribed to. We should be able to use this information so that `PHPUnit\Event\DispatchingEmitter` does not emit events that have no subscribers.

When this change is implemented then c2fcb8f1bec7773ac1d745078ba9eb4570868e11 should be reverted.

issue.title: Make export of non-scalar values for events optional

labels.name: type/enhancement
labels.description: A new idea that should be implemented

labels.name: feature/events
labels.description: Issues related to PHPUnit's event system

issue.body:
To address performance issues such as #5183 and https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/exporter/issues/18#issuecomment-1446375509, we changed the event system to not emit the `Test\AssertionSucceeded` and `Test\AssertionFailed` events when they do not have subscribers. The recently opened #5510 shows that there is at least one more performance issue related to the `Test\AssertionSucceeded` and `Test\AssertionFailed` events.

I discussed this issue with @theseer today and we came up with a different (hopefully better) solution to the performance issue that is rooted in exporting large object graphs to strings: instead of only emitting the events in question when they have subscribers, we would like to always emit them, but make the expensive export operation optional.
